name: Gender
desc_short: Between the ears, not the legs
desc_long: Gender is the range of characteristics pertaining to, and differentiating between, masculinity and femininity. Depending on the context, these characteristics may include biological sex (i.e. the state of being male, female or intersex), sex-based social structures (including gender roles and other social roles), or gender identity.

name: Akoiromantic
desc_short: Does not need to be reciprocated
desc_long: Romantic attraction which does not need to be reciprocated.

name: Ally
desc_long: Typically any non-LGBT person who supports and stands up for the rights of LGBT people, though LGBT people can be allies, such as a lesbian who is an ally to a transgender person.

name: Androgyny-Androgynous
desc_long: A gender expression that has elements of both masculinity and femininity.

name: Androphilia
desc_long: Androphilia and gynephilia are terms used in behavioral science to describe sexual orientation, as an alternative to a gender binary homosexual and heterosexual conceptualization. Androphilia describes sexual attraction to men or masculinity. The terms are objectively used for identifying a person's object of attraction without attributing a sex assignment or gender identity to the person. This can avoid bias inherent in Western conceptualizations of human sexuality, avoid confusion and offense when describing people in non-western cultures, as well as when describing intersex and transgender people, especially those who consider themselves genderqueer or otherwise falling outside the gender binary.

name: Androromantic
desc_long: Androromantic and gynoromantic are terms used in behavioral science to describe romantic orientation, as an alternative to a gender binary homoromantic and heteroromantic conceptualization. Androromantic describes romantic attraction to men or masculinity. The terms are objectively used for identifying a person's object of attraction without attributing a sex assignment or gender identity to the person. This can avoid bias inherent in Western conceptualizations of human romance, avoid confusion and offense when describing people in non-western cultures, as well as when describing intersex and transgender people, especially those who consider themselves genderqueer or otherwise falling outside the gender binary.

name: Aromantic
desc_long: Someone who experiences little or no romantic attraction to others. Aromantics are often satisfied with friendships and other non-romantic relationships.

name: Asexual
desc_long: A person who generally does not feel sexual attraction or desire to any group of people. Asexuality is not the same as celibacy.

name: Bear
desc_long: Large, hairy man who projects an image of rugged masculinity. Some bears place importance on presenting a hypermasculine image and may shun interaction with, and even disdain, men who exhibit effeminacy. The bear concept can function as an identity, an affiliation, and there is ongoing debate in bear communities about what constitutes a bear. Bears are almost always gay or bisexual men. Increasingly, transgender or transsexual men (trans men) and those who shun labels for gender and sexuality are also included within bear communities.

name: Bigender
desc_long: A person who fluctuates between traditionally 'woman' and 'man' gender-based behavior and identities, identifying with both genders (and sometimes a third gender)

name: Binding
desc_long: The term 'binding' refers to the process of flattening one's breast tissue in order to create a male-appearing chest. The type of materials and methods used for successful binding will vary depending on the size of one's chest and the overall build of one's body.

name: Biological-Sex
desc_long: The physical anatomy and gendered hormones one is born with, generally described as male, female, or intersex, and often confused with gender.

name: Biphobia
desc_short: Aversion toward bisexuality and bisexual people
desc_long: Aversion toward bisexuality and bisexual people as a social group or as individuals. People of any sexual orientation can experience such feelings of aversion. Biphobia is a source of discrimination against bisexuals, and may be based on negative bisexual stereotypes or irrational fear.

name: Bisexual
desc_long: A person who is attracted to both people of their own gender and another gender. Also called 'bi'.

name: Cisgender
desc_long: A person whose self-identity conforms with the gender that corresponds to their biological sex.

name: Cisgenderism
desc_short: Assuming every person to be cisgender
desc_long: Assuming every person to be cisgender therefore marginalizing those who identify as trans* in some form. It is also believing cisgender people to be superior, and holding people to traditional expectations based on gender, or punishing or excluding those who don't conform to traditional gender expectations.

name: Cissexism
desc_long: The fear or hatred of transgender people or gender non-conforming behavior. Like biphobia, transphobia can also exist among lesbian, gay, and bisexual people as well as among heterosexual people.

name: Cis-man
desc_long: A person who identifies as a man, presents himself masculinely, and has male biological sex, often referred to as simply 'man'

name: Cis-woman
desc_long: A person who identifies as a woman, presents herself femininely, and has female biological sex, often referred to as simply 'woman'

name: Coming-Out
desc_long: The process of acknowledging one's sexual orientation and/or gender identity to other people. For most LGBT people this is a life-long process.

name: Cross-dressing
desc_short: Wear clothing typical of the opposite gender
desc_long: Wearing clothing that conflicts with the traditional gender expression of your sex and gender identity (e.g., a man wearing a dress) for any one of many reasons, including relaxation, fun, and sexual gratification; often conflated with transsexuality.

name: Demiromantic
desc_long: Romantic attraction to person(s) only after an emotional (though not necessarily romantic) connection is formed.

name: Demisexual
desc_long: A person who does not experience sexual attraction unless they form a strong emotional connection with someone. It's more commonly seen in but by no means confined to romantic relationships. The term demisexual comes from the orientation being 'halfway between' sexual and asexual. Nevertheless, this term does not mean that demisexuals have an incomplete or half-sexuality, nor does it mean that sexual attraction without emotional connection is required for a complete sexuality.

name: Drag
desc_long: The act of dressing in gendered clothing and adopting gendered behviors as part of a performance, most often clothing and behaviors typically not associated with your gender identity. Drag Queens perform femininity theatrically. Drag Kings perform masculinity theatrically. Drag may be performed as a political comment on gender, as parody, or simply as entertainment. Drag performance does not indicate sexuality, gender identity, or sex identity.

name: Domestic-Partner
desc_long: One who lives with their beloved and/or is at least emotionally and financially connected in a supportive manner with another. Another word for spouse, lover, significant other, etc..

name: Female
desc_long: A person with a specific set of sexual anatomy (e.g., XX phenotype, vagina, ovaries, uterus, breasts, higher levels of estrogen, fine body hair) pursuant to this label.

name: Fluid
desc_long: Generally with another term attached, like gender-fluid or fluid-sexuality, fluid(ity) describes an identity that is a fluctuating mix of the options available (e.g., man and woman, gay and straight); not to be confused with 'transitioning'.

name: FTM
desc_long: A person who has undergone medical treatments to change their biological sex (Female To Male), often times to align it with their gender identity; often confused with 'trans-man'.

name: Gay
desc_long: A person who is attracted primarily to members of the same sex. Although it can be used for any sex (e.g. gay man, gay woman, gay person), 'lesbian' is sometimes the preferred term for women who are attracted to women.

name: Genderism
desc_short: Belief that gender is a binary
desc_long: The system of belief that there are only two genders (men and women) and that gender is inherently tied to one's sex assigned at birth. It holds cisgender people as superior to transgender people, and punishes or excludes those who don't conform to society's expectations of gender.

name: Gender-Binary
desc_long: The classification of sex and gender into two distinct, opposite and disconnected forms of masculine and feminine.

name: Gender-Variant
desc_short: Behavior not expected with their biological sex
desc_long: A person who either by nature or by choice does not conform to gender-based expectations of society (e.g. transgender, transsexual, intersex, genderqueer, cross-dresser, etc) preferable to 'gender variant' because it does not imply a standard normativity.

name: Gender-Expression
desc_long: A term which refers to the ways in which we each manifest masculinity or femininity. It is usually an extension of our 'gender identity,' our innate sense of being male, female, etc. Each of us expresses a particular gender every day - by the way we style our hair, select our clothing, or even the way we stand. Our appearance, speech, behavior, movement, and other factors signal that we feel - and wish to be understood - as masculine or feminine, or as a man or a woman.

name: Gender-Identity
desc_long: The sense of 'being' male, female, genderqueer, agender, etc. For some people, gender identity is in accord with physical anatomy. For transgender people, gender identity may differ from physical anatomy or expected social roles. It is important to note that gender identity, biological sex, and sexual orientation are separate and that you cannot assume how someone identifies in one category based on how they identify in another category.

name: Gender-Identity-Disorder
desc_short: Strong, persistent feelings of discomfort with one's own assigned sex
desc_long: The medical diagnosis in the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostics and Statistics Manual IV (DSM4) used to describe a person who experiences significant gender dysphoria (lack of identification with one's sex and/or gender assigned at birth). It is anticipated that the DSM5 (released in 2013) will replace this diagnosis with 'gender dysphoria'.

name: Gender-Neutral
desc_short: Cannot be taken to refer to one gender only
desc_long: Inclusive language to describe relationships ('spouse' and 'partner' instead of 'husband/boyfriend' and 'wife/girlfriend'), spaces (gender-neutral/inclusive restrooms are for use by all genders), pronouns ('they' and 'ze' are gender neutral/inclusive pronouns) among other things.

name: Gender-Non-Conforming
desc_short: Do not follow ideas or stereotypes of binary gender
desc_long: A person who [does not] conform to society's expectations of gender expression based on the gender binary, expectations of masculinity and femininity, or how they should identify their gender.

name: Gender-Role
desc_short: A set of social norms for gender
desc_long: How 'masculine' or 'feminine' an individual acts. Societies commonly have norms regarding how males and females should behave, expecting people to have personality characteristics and/or act a certain way based on their biological sex.

name: Genderless
desc_long: A person who does not identify with any gender.

name: Genderqueer
desc_long: A term which refers to individuals or groups who 'queer' or problematize the hegemonic notions of sex, gender and desire in a given society. Genderqueer people possess identities which fall outside of the widely accepted sexual binary (i.e. 'men' and 'women'). Genderqueer may also refer to people who identify as both transgendered AND queer, i.e. individuals who challenge both gender and sexuality regimes and see gender identity and sexual orientation as overlapping and interconnected.

name: Goach
desc_long: A gay coach. Usually a gay guy that you go to for well gay advice. You can ask things such as how to find the perfect guy, nearest gay bars, finding local guys to be JUST friends, etc.

name: Grayromantic
desc_long: Blanket term for those who fall anywhere in the spectrum between Romantic and Aromantic.

name: Gynephilia
desc_long: Androphilia and gynephilia are terms used in behavioral science to describe sexual orientation, as an alternative to a gender binary homosexual and heterosexual conceptualization. Gynephilia describes the sexual attraction to women or femininity. The terms are objectively used for identifying a person's object of attraction without attributing a sex assignment or gender identity to the person. This can avoid bias inherent in Western conceptualizations of human sexuality, avoid confusion and offense when describing people in non-western cultures, as well as when describing intersex and transgender people, especially those who consider themselves genderqueer or otherwise falling outside the gender binary.

name: Gynoromantic
desc_long: Androromantic and gynoromantic are terms used in behavioral science to describe romantic orientation, as an alternative to a gender binary homoromantic and heteroromantic conceptualization. Gynoromantic describes the romantic attraction to women or femininity. The terms are objectively used for identifying a person's object of attraction without attributing a sex assignment or gender identity to the person. This can avoid bias inherent in Western conceptualizations of human romance, avoid confusion and offense when describing people in non-western cultures, as well as when describing intersex and transgender people, especially those who consider themselves genderqueer or otherwise falling outside the gender binary.

name: Hate-Crime
desc_long: Hate crime legislation often defines a hate crime as a crime motivated by the actual or perceived race, color, religion, national origin, ethnicity, gender, disability, or sexual orientation of any person.

name: Hermaphrodite
desc_long: An outdated medical term used to describe someone who is intersex; not used today as it is considered to be medically stigmatizing, and also misleading as it means a person who is 100% male and female, a biological impossibility for humans.

name: Heteroromantic
desc_long: Romantic attraction towards person(s) of one gender other than their own.

name: Heterosexism
desc_long: Behavior that grants preferential treatment to heterosexual people, reinforces the idea that heterosexuality is somehow better or more 'right' than queerness, or ignores/doesn't address queerness as existing.

name: Heterosexual
desc_long: A person who is only attracted to members of the opposite sex. Also called 'straight.'

name: Homophobia
desc_long: A range of negative attitudes and feelings toward homosexuality or people who are identified or perceived as being lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender (LGBT). It can be expressed as antipathy, contempt, prejudice, aversion, or hatred, may be based on irrational fear, and is sometimes related to religious beliefs.

name: Homoromantic
desc_long: Romantic attraction towards person(s) of the same gender.

name: Homosexual
desc_long: A clinical term for people who are attracted to members of the same sex. Some people find this term offensive.

name: Idemromantic
desc_long: Experiencing romantic and platonic feelings in the same way.

name: Intersex
desc_short: Sexual anatomy is neither male nor female
desc_long: A person whose sexual anatomy or chromosomes do not fit with the traditional markers of 'female' and 'male.' For example: people born with both 'female' and 'male' anatomy (penis, testicles, vagina, uterus); people born with XXY.

name: Internalized-phobia
desc_short: Fear and self-hate of one's own identity
desc_long: The fear and self-hate of one's own lgbtqia identity, that occurs for many individuals who have learned negative ideas about LGBT people throughout childhood.  One form of internalized oppression is the acceptance of the myths and stereotypes applied to the oppressed group.

name: It
desc_long: A pronoun used to refer to a thing; the use of 'it' as a pronoun for a person is extremely offensive in its complete dehumanization of the subject; for appropriate, gender neutral pronouns, see [the information section].

name: In-the-Closet
desc_long: Describes a person who keeps their sexual orientation or gender identity a secret from some or all people.

name: Lesbian
desc_long: A woman who is primarily attracted to other women.

name: LGBTQA
desc_short: See: MOGAI. Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender
desc_long: These acronyms refer to Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, Queer or Questioning, and Asexual or Ally. Although all of the different identities within 'LGBT' are often lumped together (and share sexism as a common root of oppression), there are specific needs and concerns related to each individual identity.

name: Male
desc_long: A person with a specific set of sexual anatomy (e.g., XY phenotype, penis, testis, higher levels of testosterone, coarse body hair, facial hair) pursuant to this label.

name: MTF
desc_long: A person who has undergone medical treatments to change their biological sex (Male To Female), often times to align it with their gender identity; often confused with 'trans-woman'.

name: Neutrois
desc_long: It refers to a gender identity which is also called null-gendered on occasion. Very little is written about this gender identity, but it is growing in recognition. Because of this, some Neutrois individuals turn to the larger androgynous or genderqueer social variations.

name: Non-Op
desc_long: A trans-identified person whose identity does not involve receiving Sexual Reassignment Surgery/Sex Confirmation Surgery

name: Outing
desc_long: When someone reveals another person's sexuality or gender identity to an individual or group, often without the person's consent or approval; not to be confused with 'coming out'.

name: Out-of-the-Closet
desc_long: Refers to varying degrees of being open about one's sexual orientation and/or sex identity or gender identity.

name: Omnisexual
desc_long: Terms used to describe people who have romantic, sexual or affectional desire for people of all genders and sexes.

name: On-T
desc_short: When a person takes the hormone testosterone.
desc_long: When a person takes the hormone testosterone.

name: Pangender
desc_long: A person whose gender identity is comprised of all or many gender expressions

name: Panromantic
desc_long: Romantic attraction to person(s) of any gender.

name: Pansexual
desc_long: A person who experiences sexual, romantic, physical, and/or spiritual attraction for members of all gender identities/expressions, not just people who fit into the standard gender binary (i.e. men and women).

name: Polyamory
desc_long: Polyamory is the practice of having multiple open, honest love relationships.

name: Polygender
desc_long: Exhibiting characteristics of multiple genders, deliberately refuting the concept of only two genders.

name: Polysexual
desc_short: Attraction to most or some genders, but not all.
desc_long: Sexual attractions or relationships with any gender or sex.

name: Post-Op
desc_long: A trans-identified person who has received Sexual Reassignment Surgery/Sex Confirmation Surgery.

name: Pre-Op
desc_long: A trans-identified person who has not received Sexual Reassignment Surgery; implies that the person does intend to receive such surgical procedures

name: Privilege
desc_long: Unearned access to resources (social power) only readily available to some people as a result of their social group membership.

name: Pronouns
desc_long: Pronouns are words like 'he, she, them', and pronoun sets are groups for pronouns like ''them, their, they're.''

name: Queer
desc_long: 1) An umbrella term sometimes used by LGBTQA people to refer to the entire LGBT community. 2) An alternative that some people use to 'queer' the idea of the labels and categories such as lesbian, gay, bisexual, etc. Similar to the concept of genderqueer. It is important to note that the word queer is an in-group term, and a word that can be considered offensive to some people, depending on their generation, geographic location, and relationship with the word.

name: Questioning
desc_long: For some, the process of exploring and discovering one's own sexual orientation, gender identity, or gender expression.

name: Quoiromantic
desc_long: Unable to distinguish the difference between romantic and platonic feelings, or cannot define romantic attraction, therefore do not know whether or not they have experienced it.

name: Rainbow-Flag
desc_short: Official flag of the LGBTIQ civil rights movement
desc_long: The Rainbow Freedom Flag was designed in 1978 by Gilbert Baker to designate the great diversity of the LGBTIQ community. It has been recognized by the International Flag Makers Association as the official flag of the LGBTIQ civil rights movement.

name: Recipromantic
desc_short: I like you if you like me
desc_long: Romantic attraction only after the other person is romantically attracted.

name: Requiesromantic
desc_short: Little/no romance due to past events
desc_long: Little to no romantic attraction because of some mental or emotional exhaustion, likely due to bad experiences of romance in the past.

name: Romantic-Orientation
desc_long: Which sex or gender with which a person is most likely to have a romantic relationship or fall in love. It is used both alternatively and side-by-side with the term sexual orientation, and is based on the perspective that sexual attraction is but a single component of a larger dynamic.

name: Same-Gender-Loving
desc_long: A term coined for African American use by activist Cleo Manago, is a description for homosexuals and bisexuals, particularly in the African American community. It emerged in the early 1990s as a culturally affirming African American homosexual identity.

name: Sex
desc_long: A medical term designating a certain combination of gonads, chromosomes, external gender organs, secondary sex characteristics and hormonal balances. Common terms are 'male', 'female' and 'intersex.'

name: Sex-Identity
desc_short: The sex that a person sees themselves as
desc_long: The sex that a person sees themselves as. This can include refusing to label oneself with a sex.

name: Sex-Reassignment-Surgery
desc_short: SRS, Surgery to match sex to sex identity
desc_long: A term used by some medical professionals to refer to a group of surgical options that alter a person's sex to match their sex identity.

name: Sexual-Orientation
desc_long: The type of sexual, romantic, and/or physical attraction someone feels toward others. Often labeled based on the gender identity/expression of the person and who they are attracted to. Common labels: lesbian, gay, bisexual, pansexual, etc.

name: Skoliosexual
desc_short: A chaser, attraction to trans people
desc_long: Attracted to genderqueer and transsexual people and expressions (people who aren't identified as cisgender).

name: Straight
desc_short: Attracted to the other binary gender
desc_long: A man or woman who is attracted to people of the other binary gender than themselves; often referred to as 'heterosexual'.

name: Third-Gender
desc_long: (1) A person who does not identify with the traditional genders of 'man' or 'woman', but identifies with another gender; (2) the gender category available in societies that recognize three or more genders.

name: Transgender
desc_short: Does not conform to conventional male / female gender
desc_long: Denoting or relating to a person whose self-identity does not conform unambiguously to conventional notions of male or female gender.

name: Transitioning
desc_short: Process of moving from one sex/gender to another
desc_long: A term used to describe the process of moving from one sex/gender to another, sometimes this is done by hormone or surgical treatments.

name: Transmisogyny
desc_long: The fear or hatred of transgender people or gender non-conforming behavior. Like biphobia, transphobia can also exist among lesbian, gay, and bisexual people as well as among heterosexual people.

name: Transphobia
desc_long: The fear or hatred of transgender people or gender non-conforming behavior. Like biphobia, transphobia can also exist among lesbian, gay, and bisexual people as well as among heterosexual people.

name: Transsexual
desc_short: Someone's gender identity is different that biological sex
desc_long: A person whose gender identity is different from their biological sex, who may undergo medical treatments to change their biological sex, often times to align it with their gender identity, or they may live their lives as another sex.

name: Transvestite
desc_long: A person who dresses as the binary opposite gender expression ('cross-dresses') for any one of many reasons, including relaxation, fun, and sexual gratification; often called a 'cross-dresser', and often confused with 'transsexual'.

name: Trans-man
desc_short: Trans and identifies as a man
desc_long: A transgender person who was assigned female at birth but whose gender identity is that of a man.

name: Trans-woman
desc_short: Trans and identifies as a woman
desc_long: A transgender person who was assigned male at birth but whose gender identity is that of a woman.

name: Trigger
desc_long: Words or phrases that stimulate an emotional response because they tap into anger or pain about oppression issues.

name: Two-Spirit
desc_long: A term traditionally used by Native American people to recognize individuals who possess qualities or fulfill roles of both genders.

name: Ursula
desc_long: Feminization of the word ursine, meaning of or pertaining to a bear, resembling a bear. Most lesbian bears are butch, fat or stockily built and sometimes taller than average. Like their gay male counterparts who tend to be hairy, female bears often resist shaving their legs and underarms, while coveting any facial hair that appears. Ursulas are down-to-earth and are usually found in jeans or leather.

name: Gender-Euphoria
desc_long: The opposite of gender dysphoria. For a cisgender person, it is a state of happiness about being male or female and having the associated gender roles and body parts. For a transgender person, it refers to feeling great about living as your desired gender. Examples include 'having a penis is so awesome it gives me serious gender euphoria!' or 'my gender dysphoria has turned into euphoria lately now that strangers are gendering me correctly!'

name: Angenital
desc_short: Physical dysphoria but no social dysphoria
desc_long: An identity in which one feels uncomfortable or dysphoric with having any sort of genitals or sex organs but do not have any dysphoria or uncomfortableness with any particular pronoun or gender-related labels. This identity has a desire to be sexless but not necessarily genderless. This identity is often paired with other identities.

name: Enbious
desc_short: The appreciation or awe of someone's queerness to the point of envy.
desc_long: The appreciation or awe of someone's queerness to the point of envy.

name: Truscum
desc_long: A combination of the words 'true' and 'scum'. A term for transmedicalists who are trans or nonbinary.

name: Harry-Benjamin-Syndrome
desc_long: Named after a sexologist and endocrinologist who was responsible for creating the first requirements for being diagnosed as a transgender ('transexual' back then) person. HBS-ers still believe and advocate that idea.

name: Transmedicalist
desc_short: Belief that physical dysphoria is required for someone to identify as trans
desc_long: A person who believes that being trans is a disorder, and thus that physical dysphoria, usually in rather specific areas, is required for someone to identify as trans. They usually do not believe in nonbinary genders or only believe in a specific few, like agender.

name: CA-X-AB
desc_long: Coercively assigned (gender, typically 'm' or 'f') at birth. Used only for intersex individuals.

name: FA-X-AB
desc_long: Forcibly assigned (gender, typically 'm' or 'f') at birth. Used only for those who have undergone genital mutilation.

name: IA-X-AB
desc_long: Incorrectly/intersex assigned (gender, typically 'm' or 'f') at birth. Intersex specific term.

name: Nonbinary-Erasure
desc_short: When nonbinary people seem to not exist
desc_long: A term for the specific issues nonbinary people face when it does not fall into the following categories: 1) transphobia, 2) transmisogyny, 3) binarism.

name: Cisnormativity
desc_long: The idea that being cis is the default and being trans or nonbinary are options away from the default.

name: Binarism
desc_short: Erasure of nonbinary PoC due to colonialism
desc_long: A term for the erasure and violence nonbinary PoC face(d) during and after colonialism as they were forced into binary genders.

name: Auxiliary-Set-Pronoun
desc_short: Secondary pronoun set to help adjust
desc_long: A secondary pronoun set provided for developmentally disabled people who cannot or take a long time adjusting to your primary pronoun set(s). (ie, 'my pronouns are fae/faer or ze/hir, aux set they/them') The following pronoun sets are good for use as auxiliary pronouns: she/her, he/him, they/them, it/its.

name: Physical-Dysphoria
desc_long: Gender dysphoria in relation to one's body parts, like hips, jaw, chest, genitals, etc..

name: Social-Dysphoria
desc_long: Gender dysphoria in relation to social aspects like being misgendered, the way one presents, etc..

name: TERF
desc_long: Trans exclusionary/exterminatory radical feminist

name: Trans-Feminine
desc_short: A dmab person who identifies as feminine
desc_long: A dmab person who identifies as trans feminine, usually being partially or mostly feminine in their gender and/or presentation.

name: Trans-Masculine
desc_short: A dfab person who identifies as masculine
desc_long: A dfab person who identifies as trans masculine, usually being partially or mostly masculine in their gender and/or presentation.

name: TWERF
desc_long: Trans women exclusionary/exterminatory radical feminist.

name: Demigirl
desc_short: Partially female and some other gender
desc_long: A gender experience which is composed partially of feeling female and partially of some other sort of gender experience.

name: Demiboy
desc_short: Partially male and some other gender
desc_long: A gender experience which is composed partially of feeling male and partially of some other sort of gender experience.

name: Dyadic
desc_long: Dyadic is a word used to refer to people who are not intersex. Like the term cisgender, it was created to avoid othering of intersex people by referring to non-intersex people as 'normal.'

name: Gendersolid
desc_short: A gender that does not change over time
desc_long: A gender experience which does not change in nature or intensity over time.

name: Genderpunk
desc_short: A gender that is punk in nature
desc_long: A gender experience which is punk in nature or intensity.

name: Autosexual
desc_long: Being sexually attracted to oneself.

name: Ambigender
desc_short: Having two genders simultaneously without fluidity
desc_long: Experiencing two genders simultaneously and without fluidity or shifting,

name: Cassgender
desc_long: Feeling utterly indifferent to gender, believing it is not important.

name: Egogender
desc_short: A gender that is solely based on yourself
desc_long: A gender that is solely based on yourself, and no words seem to define it other than me gender, [name] gender, I'm just who I am and my gender is mine. Latin/Greek prefix ego, meaning self, I (first person).

name: Apconsusgender
desc_short: A gender defined by what it is not
desc_long: A gender where you know what it is not, but not what it is. Like the gender is hiding itself from you. From the Latin word absconsus, meaning hidden, secret, concealed, unknown.

name: Straight-Washing
desc_short: Attempting to change someone's sexuality to be heterosexual
desc_long: A person whose true sexual orientation is anything other than heterosexual or asexual, and has assimilated to heterosexual cultural norms, mores and folkways. This person may also deal with issues of internalized homophobia.

name: Gender-Dysphoria
desc_short: The discontent experienced by some persons resulting from gender identity issues.
desc_long: Gender dysphoria or gender identity disorder (GID) is the formal diagnosis used by psychologists and physicians to describe people who experience significant dysphoria (discontent) with the sex and gender they were assigned at birth. Evidence suggests that people who identify with a gender different from the one they were assigned at birth, may do so not just due to psychological or behavioral causes, but also biological ones related to their genetics, the makeup of their brains, or prenatal exposure to hormones.

name: Genderfluid
desc_short: A gender which varies over time
desc_long:
A gender identity which refers to a gender which varies over time. A gender fluid person may at any time identify as male, female, neutrois, or any other non-binary identity, or some combination of identities. Their gender identity can vary at random or in response to different circumstances. Gender fluid people may also identify as multigender, non-binary and/or transgender.

Gender fluid people who feel that their strength of identification changes over time, or that they are sometimes agender, may identify as gender flux.

name: Agender
desc_long: Agender is a term which can be literally translated as 'without gender'. It can be seen either as a non-binary gender identity or as a statement of not having a gender identity. People who identify as agender may describe themselves as one or more of the following: genderless or lacking gender, gender neutral, having an unknown or undefinable gender; not aligning with any gender, having no words that fit their gender identity, not knowing or not caring about gender, deciding not to label their gender, or identifying more as a person than any gender at all.

name: Abrosexual
desc_long: An individual that has a fluid or rapidly changing sexuality that fluctuates between different sexualities.

name: Apothisexual
desc_long: Someone who identifies as asexual and is sex repulsed.
